ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I got a very good basis in the Chinese language, especially in terms of pronunciation, grammar, and important writing background. I honestly felt like this was a really comprehensive start to eventually becoming fluent in Chinese.
Solid understanding of grammar structures and vocabulary in Chinese
Basic knowledge of Chinese grammar and vocabulary

I developed an understanding of basic Mandarin including reading, writing, speaking, and listening. Starting with no background, I am now able to have very basic conversations with others and write down what I have done during the day.
Ive learnt a lot about Chinese culture, how to introduce my self, talk about my hobbies, how to ask for directions

I've gained a comprehensive knowledge of the fundamental topics taught within the lessons of Chinese L1. Conversational skills, grammar rules, and tone recognition were a couple of the many skills that the class has helped me begin to polish.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: There was little time to practice but the course materials were very well prepared and taught.

Strengths: lots of practice speaking, excellent teachers, good class organization
Weaknesses: I feel like less homework and MORE time spent in class would actually help accelerate learning. Speaking practice in class was one of the best things for me.
The course is very well organized. It is a lot of work, but I wouldnt view that as a weakness - more an indicator that this is by no means an easy class.

Strength - meeting every day and having manageable homework everyday ensures you are always on top of the work

Weakness - it seems at times that the standardized test across sections causes difficulty when sections aren't learning at the same speeds.
The course is very engaging and interactive. My teacher was also extremely helpful. She was the best.
The courseload is immense but not intellectually challenging. I was devoting 2 hours a day on practicing Chinese and doing the Chinese homework.

Instructor was very good, pace of course was very fast but not impossible. My least favorite aspect of the course was CANVAS. Canvas made it so difficult for me to go back and review homework, tests, and quizzes that I would often not do any review at all. If not for the links in the Microsoft Word weekly schedule we download from the website, I would not have been able to find anything on Canvas.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: The grading is harsh but you definitely learn a lot.
Yes. I really enjoyed this class and I felt it was a great introduction to the Chinese language. Also, Wang Laoshi was amazing.
Yes, just be prepared to put in the work.
If they wanted to learn Chinese then yes, otherwise, this is a very difficult language course.
Yes - it was a great opportunity to learn a difficult language outside of the country, and my instructor was good. The small class size also helped us get to know each other better.
